title: received speed is slow
body:

`GC: 13906306` = 53Gb (of deleted space) quite a lot - because you don't use `--prune` flag (means we don't delete old data). but because each sync cycle is big - it updating much "mutable" data. It's one of step inside Commit and this step will get faster in 1-2 days (as gc get smaller). 
To understand speed of different steps inside Commit: can add --metrics flag and after 1-2 hours of work show `curl http://erigon:6060/debug/metrics/prometheus`

I wonderd whether the version i used is too old?  

> `GC: 13906306` = 53Gb (of deleted space) quite a lot - because you don't use `--prune` flag (means we don't delete old data). but because each sync cycle is big - it updating much "mutable" data. It's one of step inside Commit and this step will get faster in 1-2 days (as gc get smaller). To understand speed of different steps inside Commit: can add --metrics flag and after 1-2 hours of work show `curl http://erigon:6060/debug/metrics/prometheus`

does that mean rebooting erigon cli with --prune flag can make sync speed up?

I tried to use `--prune`  flag but I found it was not allowed to be changed.
Does the `--prune.h.older value` or `--prune.r.older value` can also delete old data?

You don’t need —prune flag. Also can’t change this flag, if change it will cause bigger problem. 

“ the version i used is too old?” - can be, hard to say.
Let’s add —metrics flag and wait 1 day

The HDD disk you are using is very poorly suited for such a workload (a lot of random I/O).
You can get about ×100-1000 performance using a suitable SSD, for instance: WDS400T1R0A, MTFDKCB6T4TFC-1AZ1ZAB.
For extreme a PCI-E SSD: GP-ASACNE6800TTTDA, SSDPF2NV307TZN1, DCP5800X (upto ×10000-50000 of current performance with 7200rpm HDD), etc.

1. Warn against HDD - done https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/commit/7ddb7ad562c4eac456eccf225bbfdfbec3601814
2. Yes, it's well known - that Erigon can't work well on HDD (at least big chains: mainnet, bsc, ...). It will always stay N blocks behind (10 or 10_000 depend on HDD latency), but will not fall behind more than this N. It's may be acceptable in some use-cases - where you never need be on top of chain - for example if you only do old history analytics and don't need low JSON RPC latency. But it's rare use-case.

> @AskAlexSharov, думаю вам стоит в системных требованиях категорически предостерегать от использования HDD. В качестве исключения можно рекомендовать 2-4 Тб ОЗУ и RAID с кэшем обратной записи. Но размещать на одном шпиндельном диске БД размером в 2-4 Тб с преимущественно случайным сценарием доступа - это уже техническая неадекватность.
> 
> @AskAlexSharov, I think you should categorically warn against using HDD in the system requirements. As an exception, you can recommend 2-4 TB of RAM and RAID with a write-back cache. But it is totally unreasonable placing a 2-4 TB database with a mostly random access scenario on a single HDD.

Ohh no, Sorry for my mistake of using wrong command to check disk information, so that i mistakenly thought I was using a SSD.

> 1. Warn against HDD - done [7ddb7ad](https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/commit/7ddb7ad562c4eac456eccf225bbfdfbec3601814)
> 2. Yes, it's well known - that Erigon can't work well on HDD (at least big chains: mainnet, bsc, ...). It will always stay N blocks behind (10 or 10_000 depend on HDD latency), but will not fall behind more than this N. It's may be acceptable in some use-cases - where you never need be on top of chain - for example if you only do old history analytics and don't need low JSON RPC latency. But it's rare use-case.

I do always need the highest block for real-time analysis. I will negotiate with my mentor for changing to a SSD. Thanks for your patient answer.
For people who using Erigon's `devel` branch with `--prune` flag of version after "4 April" - please update. Just fixed bug which making sync on tip of chain slow.
